MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Russian Army Deserters.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Kitt Mr. M. Kitt
Qst.Quest: if her Department was contacted by the two men who claimed to be Russian army deserters; if so, when; the amount paid by her Department in respect of their travel arrangements to Great Britain; whether they applied for refugee status; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: It is not the practice to comment publicly on individual applications for refugee status having regard to the fact that applications by their nature are made in confidence, with an expectation by applicants that such confidence will be preserved.

However, in this instance, due to the fact that the individuals in question have already revealed certain details in the media, I can confirm some aspects of their case. They arrived in Galway on 12 April 1996 and applied for political asylum. They had, however, already entered the State on 2 April 1996, having travelled here from the United Kingdom where they had arrived on 23 March 1996 and where they had been granted visitors' conditions. They applied on that first visit for political asylum at my Department, using names and nationalities different to those published. They were informed by officials of my Department that their application for political asylum would not be processed in this country in line with the internationally accepted practice that asylum seekers should apply in the first safe country reached and that they had the opportunity to make such an application in the United Kingdom.

MainHeading.P: They were refused leave to land in this State on 3 April 1996 as they were not in possession of valid Irish visas. Prior to taking this action, the United Kingdom authorities had been consulted and had agreed to accept both individuals back and to process their applications for political asylum. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees had also been contacted and agreed that this was the appropriate course. They returned to the United Kingdom on 3 April 1996 at a cost of £208 to the State.
The present whereabouts of the two individuals is unknown and the matter has been referred to the Garda authorities for their attention.

The publicity accorded to the two men in this case highlights the need for great caution on the part of the media and of agencies dealing with asylum seekers. The level of attention accorded to these two could, in the case of genuine fugitives from prosecution, run the risk of endangering family or other connections in the home countries. I might add that I understand that the publicity in this case was sought by the individuals concerned against the advice of the local Red Cross Society.

The Refugee Bill, 1995, which is before the Seanad at the moment, having passed all Stages in this House, contains provisions to protect the identity of asylum seekers. Pending the enactment of these provisions into law, there is, I believe, merit in encouraging persons who may be disposed to make public comment to voluntarily observe the principles underlying these identity protection provisions.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to recruit additional gardaí; and if so, when.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The current Garda recruitment competition covers the period 1994 to 1997. I expect to submit my proposals for Garda recruitment in the ensuing three to four year period to Government later this year.

Qst.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to prevent the sale of illegal drugs on licensed premises.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Last year I obtained Government approval for a series of organisational, financial, operational and legislative measures to deal with the drug problem. A number of those measures have been implemented and others are in the process of being implemented.

In addition to those measures which are directed at the drugs problem in general I have in mind more specific measures aimed at licensed premises, including dance halls, where drug sales are suspected. One such measure, which concerns Garda powers of entry to premises where a public dance hall licence is in force, is the subject of an amendment tabled by me to the Criminal Justice (Drug Trafficking) Bill, 1996, which is currently before the House. My further proposals in this area will be announced in the usual way in due course.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Organised Crime.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Brennan Mr. M. Brennan
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to introduce measures with a view to tackling contract killings and gangland murders.
the plans, if any, she has to tackle organised crime.
the steps, if any, she intends to take with a view to tackling organised crime.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 45, 55 and 85 together.

MainHeading.P: All crimes are fully investigated by the Garda and every possible effort is made to bring the perpetrators to justice. As regards crimes committed by criminal gangs in particular, I know that there is public concern about the number of murders which have been attributed to such gangs by the media. In this regard, I can assure you that the Garda allocate optimum resources to the investigation of all murders. The primary task, of course, is to identify those responsible and to assemble evidence to support the institution of legal proceedings. In addition, special attention is also directed to the motivation involved.

Crimes of this nature are investigated by divisional investigation teams, the membership of which includes detective gardaí who have been trained in the investigation of serious crime. The gardaí involved in these investigations know the local community and they work in close proximity to sources of intelligence. The divisional investigation teams are assisted by gardaí from the Garda Technical Bureau who provide specialised services such as ballistics, photography and fingerprints.

In addition to providing assistance to the divisional units, the Serious Crime Squad at the Central Detective Unit has the task of gathering intelligence and information on all serious crime. Every effort is made in the examination and collation of this material to establish if the crimes are linked in any way. This includes, in the case of murder, trying to establish if there is a common perpetrator for two or more offences.

The Garda authorities are satisfied that maximum resources are deployed to solve all murder cases including the identification of possible so-called contract killers. A focus of activity of many criminal gangs is, of course, the drugs trade, and I have made the fight against drugs a matter of the highest priority for both my Department and the Garda. Last year, I obtained the approval of Government for a series of organisational, financial, legislative and operational measures to deal with the drugs problem. A number of these measures have been implemented and others are in the process of being implemented. In particular, the Garda National Drugs Unit has been established and this unit is currently engaged in tackling the menace posed by drug trafficking gangs.

It is also important to target the proceeds of crime. Last year, I made a commencement order that brought sections 32 and 57 of the Criminal Justice Act, 1994, into operation. These sections require banks and other financial bodies to carry out identification checks to prevent money laundering and to report to the Garda Síochána where they suspect that laundering is taking place relation to their business. They supplement other provisions of the Act, in particular, the money laundering offence and the power to confiscate criminal proceeds and to obtain restraint orders to seize and freeze suspected criminal assets which came into force on 14 November 1994.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Appeals Against Severity of Sentences.

Qst.Quest: the number of cases in each of the past three years in which defendants have appealed against the severity of their sentence; the number of such appeals that were successful; the role of the State in such appeals; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The number of appeals lodged in the legal year ending 31 July 1993, 31 July 1994 and 31 July 1995 against District Court orders is as follows:

row.entry: Number of District Court Convictions Appealed

MainHeading.P: A defendant can appeal against the conviction and sentence or against the severity of sentence only. The statistics available on District Court appeals do not distinguish between the grounds of appeals. Statistics are not available on the results of these appeals.

Appeals against orders made in the Circuit Criminal Court, the Central Criminal Court and the Special Criminal Court are made to the Court of Criminal Appeal. The latest figures available for the number of appeals to the Court of Criminal Appeal are for the legal year ending 31 July 1993 and these are as follows:

row.entry: Number of appeals received in Year ending 31-07-93
Number of Appeals Heard in Year ending 31-07-1993

MainHeading.P: Results of the Appeals heard in the Court of Criminal Appeal in year ending 31-07-93
Figures for appeals to the Court of Criminal Appeal for years ending 31 July 1994 and 31 July 1995 are being compiled at present. When the figures become available I will forward them to the Deputy.

All appeals are handled on behalf of the Director of Public Prosecutions by the Chief State Solicitor's Office. Appeals from District Court orders are heard in the Circuit Court and a solicitor from the Chief State Solicitor's office represents the DPP in court. Barristers instructed by the Chief State Solicitor's office represent the DPP in the Court of Criminal Appeal. The decision to grant or refuse an appeal is a matter for the courts which are subject only to the Constitution and the law independent in the exercise of their judicial functions.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to amend the licensing laws with regard to the sale of intoxicating liquor.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I have no plans at present to amend the liquor licensing laws.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mountjoy Jail Overcrowding.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, she has to alleviate the overcrowding in Mountjoy Jail; the current prison population in the jail; its population capacity; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Mountjoy prison currently has a capacity of 556 male and 40 female prisoners. It constantly operates at maximum capacity and this is exceeded from time to time. The prisoner population there has gone as high as 643.

The position in relation to the provision of additional prison places is as I announced at the end of January last. I am proceeding with planning and construction works for the provision of the 278 additional places I promised earlier this year. Already, 33 additional places were brought into use at St. Patrick's Institution in February and a further 38 places, which were out of use arising from extensive fire damage at the health care unit, Mountjoy, in December 1995, will be ready for re-occupation in the near future following major repair and fire safety works at the Unit.

MainHeading.P: Construction works for the conversion of the military detention unit at the Curragh to a civil prison to accommodates 68 offenders, which is a somewhat higher figure than I announced in January, were commenced within the past week and are due for completion in the autumn of this year. Works for the construction of a prison unit at Castlerea to accommodate 25 offenders have commenced and these places are expected to come on stream around August-September this year.

At Portlaoise prison, a series of works necessary for the recovery of up to 80 cell spaces now vacant due to operational requirements or used to accommodate a range of necessary offender facilities have been commenced and are due for completion within the current year.

In the slightly longer term, I am pushing forward with plans for the provision of a replacement for the closed down and near-derelict D-Wing at Limerick prison. The new wing will accommodate 55 offenders. Construction is planned to commence towards the end of this year and to be completed in 1997.

I am also progressing works for the planning and design of the new women's prison at Cowley Place beside Mountjoy prison to accommodate 60 offenders and for the main prison development at Castlerea for male offenders.
All of these developments will help to alleviate the situation in Mountjoy and, indeed, the other institutions under my jurisdiction.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. Ryan Mr. E. Ryan
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to set out definitive guidelines in relation to promotion within the ranks of the Garda Síochána.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Promotion within An Garda Síochána is governed by the provisions of the Garda Síochána (Promotion) Regulations, 1987, as amended by the Garda Síochána (Promotion) (Amendment) Regulations, 1990 and 1993. These regulations were made by the Minister for Justice, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 14 of the Police Forces (Amalgamation) Act, 1925, and with the approval of the Government.

Qst.Quest: the procedures in place within her Department to investigate and review the handling of any particular Garda investigation where it is deemed appropriate; the reviews, if any, that are ongoing; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Criminal investigations are operational matters and, as such, are the responsibility of the Garda Commissioner. Accordingly, the review of the handling of any particular investigation is a matter for the commissioner.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Investigation of Serious Crime.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to allow a designated section of the Garda Síochána to work unspecified and self-discretionary hours in pursuit of serious offenders.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The allocation of Garda personnel and resources is a matter for the Garda authorities. They have informed me that in the investigation of serious crime, they allocate the necessary resources for proper investigation of that particular crime. Where flexibility or additional resources are required, investigation teams are employed accordingly or supplemented by additional gardaí. There are no plans at present to allow a designated section of the Garda Síochána to work unspecified and self-discretionary hours.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to reform Garda training.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Garda Training Centre, based in Templemore, provides for a continuum of education training from student Garda stage up to the development of officers at the highest level, and is divided into five schools as follows:
1. Student/Probationer;
2. In-Service;
3. Specialist;
4. Promotion;
5. Management.

On joining the force a student-probationer undergoes a two year comprehensive education-training programme. Continuing education-training and development is provided for at regular intervals as members progress within the force.

The training and development of all Garda personnel is subject to continuous evaluation and review. The design, structure and content of courses continue to evolve in the light of best practice in this field and the operational requirements of the force.

Qst.Quest: whether she has recently imposed a complete blanket on parole for republican prisoners in Portlaoise Prison, County Laois; and if so, the reason therefor.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: There is no blanket ban on parole for republican prisoners in Portlaoise prison. The full restoration of the parole arrangements which existed immediately prior to the resumption of violence on 9 February last is something which will fall to be considered in the event of the cessation being restored. In the meantime the position is that each parole application will be considered on its merits.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Ahern Mr. M. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to improve security in respect of the carriage of prisoners and large sums of money.

the implications, if any, of the recent assisted escape of a prisoner en route to a court appearance from Portlaoise prison, County Laois; the circumstances and security arrangements surrounding this event; the proposals, if any, she has to improve the security for such escorts; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 57 and 160 together.

I have received preliminary reports from the Governor of Portlaoise Prison and the Garda Síochána concerning the escape of the prisoner referred to in Question No. 160. As soon as I have received the final reports on the matter I will carry out, in conjunction with the prison authorities and the Garda Síochána, a through re-assessment of the situation regarding prisoner escorts generally. In the meantime it would not be appropriate to make any further comment.

As regards cash in transit, there is ongoing close liaison between the Garda Síochána, the Defence Forces, financial institutions and the security industry in regard to protection of the movement and storage of large sums of money. I am satisfied that there have been important recent enhancements in these protection arrangements and that the question of further such enhancements can best be considered in the context of continued liaison.

Qst.Quest: her most recent response to the requests by the relatives of the Dublin-Monaghan bombing victims in view of undertakings given by her in October 1995 arising out of the RTE "Prime Time" broadcast of May 1995; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Qst.Quest: asked the Minister for Justice the steps, if any, she has taken in recent times in relation to investigating and publishing the circumstances of the Dublin and Monaghan bombings of 17 May 1974; and whether her Department now regards the matter as closed; and if she will make a statement on the matter. [10017/96]

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 58 and 133 together. On foot of the undertakings referred to in Question No. 58, I informed the relatives of the victims — as well as Deputy Harney and other Members of this House — by way of letters dated 29 February 1996 that the Garda authorities were satisfied from their assessment of the “Prime Time” broadcast of May 1995 that no new evidence or witness had been identified which would provide a basis for further Garda investigation.
I am assured by the Garda authorities that the Garda investigation file on the 1974 Dublin and Monaghan bombings will continue to remain open and that any new leads will be actively pursued.

Qst.Quest: the number of juvenile offenders currently serving sentences in the State; the proportion of the total prison population that these offenders comprise; the number of such offenders that are drug abusers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: On 15 April 1996 there were 60 juvenile offenders — under 17 years of age — in custody. This comprised approximately 3 per cent of the total number in custody on the above date. Records are not maintained in such a manner as to indicate the proportion of juveniles who may or may not be drug abusers and individual prisoner's medical records are, in any event, confidential in the context of the doctor-patient relationship.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, she has made in relation to the fine petition process.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: New procedures which I believe may be necessary as a result of the High Court judgment on petitions are the subject of ongoing examination and I am not yet in a position to make an announcement on the matter.

Qst.Quest: whether she intends to introduce an offence of drug-dealing for substantial monetary gain with a minimum sentence of imprisonment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Deputy will be aware that the Criminal Justice (Drug Trafficking) Bill is at present before the Select Committee on Legislation and Security and that his colleague, Deputy O'Donoghue, has put down an amendment along the lines of the question. I will, of course, respond to this matter fully when the amendment is being debated.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Use of Offensive Weapons.

Qst.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Qst.Quest: the further consideration, if any, she has given to the crime of assault with blood-filled syringes by drug addicts and others in view of her reply to Parliamentary Question No. 6 on 11 May 1995; if she has studied the recommendations on the issue from the AGSI conference in Bundoran of 2 April 1996; and the immediate steps, if any, she will take to make it a serious criminal offence in view of the potentially harrowing and fatal consequences of this type of crime.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am aware of and understand the concerns expressed by delegates to last months AGSI conference about the use of syringes as offensive weapons.

However, as I indicated in some detail in my reply to the Deputy's question on 11 May 1995 our criminal law already includes severe penalties for offences involving the use of a syringe in the course of committing a robbery or other offence and the possession of a syringe in a public place.

I am at present preparing legislation to reform the law relating to non-fatal offences against the person and if I believe that some further strengthening of the law in this area is required or would produce some actual benefit I will certainly consider it in that context.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Land Registry Computerisation.

Qst.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to computerise the Land Registry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: A considerable investment is being made in computerisation and information technology in the Land Registry and the Registry of Deeds. Development work is also being undertaken in relation to digital mapping, training, strategic management and the installation in the registries of modern financial and accounting systems.
An information technology strategic plan for the registries is in place. This plan comprises a total of 33 different projects of which 12 have been completed to date and four are under way.

An application tracking system which is designed to enable the Land Registry to trace and manage its ever increasing caseload of applications has been installed in the Kildare-Wicklow regional group and in the Cork regional group to date. It is hoped to extend this application tracking system to other counties in the near future.

MainHeading.P: In line with the registries IT strategic plan, a digital mapping feasability study to evaluate the issues and business case for digital mapping in the Land Registry has just been completed and a report is being prepared on this subject.

A wide area network providing direct electronic communications between the Land Registry offices in Irish Life Centre and Aras Uí Dhálaigh has also been installed. This network was extended to the Registry of Deeds to allow searching of the abstract record database to take place from Irish Life. A major data capture programme of abstracts in the Registry of Deeds was completed in 1994 resulting in a computerised searching facility for the public. These achievements have provided a much improved and speedy service to the public.

I should also mention that some of the Land Registry's present accommodation will not support computerisation on the scale envisaged for the Land Registry and that plans are currently afoot to provide the registries with accommodation which will support computerisation.

Qst.Quest: her views on the deployment of 18 senior gardaí to observe five people laying a wreath on the grave of a republican who died from natural causes some years ago considering the many demands being made on the Garda Síochána in other areas of crime and the escalating problem of drugs trafficking in particular.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The detailed deployment of Garda manpower is a matter for the Garda authorities. They inform me that it is not possible, on the basis of the information supplied, to identify the occasion referred in the question. Should the Deputy provide more detailed information, I will have further inquiries made in the matter.

Qst.Quest: whether she intends to introduce guidelines with a view to dealing with domestic violence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Garda authorities have been endeavouring since the establishment in March 1993 of the domestic violence and sexual assault investigation unit at DMA Headquarters in Harcourt Square, Dublin 2 to deal more effectively with domestic violence. The unit is staffed by gardaí who are trained and experienced in dealing with domestic violence and sexual assaults.

The functions of the unit include overseeing the investigation of offences of domestic violence, child sexual abuse and other violent and sexual offences committed against women and children and enforcement practices in respect of protection and barring orders. The unit works in close contact with the Garda community relations section and liaises with organisations, both statutory and voluntary, which deal with violent or sexual crime against women and children.

In 1994, the Garda Commissioner issued a pro-arrest policy document on the procedures to be followed by the gardaí in incidents of domestic violence. The primary concern of the gardaí in such circumstances is for the protection of the victims of domestic violence through law enforcement. The policy document sets out the manner in which investigations should be conducted and reported.

Outside of the Dublin metropolitan area, the Garda authorities have designated an inspector in each Garda division to have overall responsibility for this area and to ensure a uniform and consistent approach. This plan of action was implemented in April 1994 and is the subject of ongoing review by the Garda authorities.
Statistical information on the incidence of domestic violence is now being generated and published in the annual report on crime.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Electronic Tagging of Offenders.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to introduce electronic tagging of habitual criminal offenders.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am glad to have the opportunity of outlining my plans in this regard. I am committed to the development of community sanctions and measures, together with planned and programmed release of offencers under the supervision of the probation and welfare service. In this context, I am having the matter of electronic tagging examined by my Department and I am closely monitoring the progress of a number of European schemes which have been set up on a pilot basis. When this examination is carried out I will then decide how best to progress our interests. I can tell the House, however, that the initial response which I am getting from some jurisdictions to electronic tagging is less than enthusiastic, not least on cost grounds. There would also be some additional problems for us. For example, it is essential that the offender has a telephone which would not always be the case here. However, as I have indicated, I will make a decision on this matter as soon as my Department has concluded its examination.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prison Projects.

Qst.Quest: when the prisons at Castlerea and Mountjoy will be fully operational.
the anticipated completion date of proposed prisons at Castlerea and Mountjoy.

the current position regarding the Castlerea prison project, County Roscommon; the original completion date in respect of this project; the current likely timescale for completion of this project; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 69, 77 and 148 together.

As I announced earlier this year, the development of the Castlerea prison project will take place in phases. The first phase was the completion of the perimeter wall. As a second phase I propose to construct a special secure unit to accommodate 25 offenders. A contract has been place for initial works and tenders for the provision of the new buildings for this unit have recently been received and are being examined at present. I expect to be a position to place a contract for these works very shortly and to have them completed by August-September.

The original proposals for the main prison development at Castlerea, Phase 3, while incorporating the use of the existing hospital buildings, envisaged a significant amount of new, purpose-designed buildings in the overall plan. I have directed that a comprehensive review of the original plans be undertaken with a view to maximising the use of the existing hospital buildings and confining new buildings largely to cellular accommodation. My Department, with the assistance of the Office of Public Works, is proceeding with planning and design works for this proposed facility. Normally, projects of this size and nature could be expected to be completed in a period of 20 to 27 months.

I am not in a position, at this stage, to indicate when this new prison facility will be completed or to confirm the number of places to be provided other than to say that the overall number to be accommodated at Castlerea will be of the order envisaged in the original plan.

MainHeading.P: In regard to the new women's prison, with the approval of Government, I had work on the planning and design of this facility to accommodate 60 offenders and located on the Cowley Place site, beside Mountjoy Prison, recommenced earlier this year and it is being progressed at present. Planning and related matters are being progressed and until these matters are completed it is not yet possible to give a definite date for the completion of the project.

Qst.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Qst.Quest: whether the continuance of the common travel area has been raised in discussion with her by the British Prime Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The arrangements in place to enable persons to travel between this State and the United Kingdom — the common travel area — without being subject to immigration controls in either country have not been raised by the British Prime Minister in any discussions he has had with the Taoiseach or with me.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Visa and Naturalisation Applications.

Qst.Quest: the number of visa and naturalisation applications received by her Department in 1995; the number of applications granted; the proposals, if any, she has for bringing forward the proposed legislative package on non-nationals and, in particular, injecting increased transparency into the system; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: A total of 295 applications for naturalisation were received in my Department in 1995 and 355 certificates of naturalisation were issued in 1995 — this higher figure is accounted for by the fact that no valid comparisons can be made between applications received and certificates issued in any given year. For example, in 1995 significant inroads were made into a backlog of applications which had accumulated over the previous years and thence a comparatively larger number of cases were finalised during the year.

A total of 242 declarations of post nuptial citizenship were also lodged in my Department in 1995 and 133 post nuptial declarations were accepted during the year. Valid comparisons cannot be made between these figures over a given year.
In addition to these cases, a total of 415 declarations of post nuptial citizenship were accepted in Irish embassies throughout the world in 1995.

As regards visas, the Department of Foreign Affairs, which is the visa-issuing authority of the State, has not yet finalised the figures for 1995. However, it is estimated that the number of visa applications received was in the region of 30,000. This compares with 23,545 applications in 1994, of which over 21,000, or 95 per cent, were granted. The indications for the figures for 1995 are that the number of applications granted was also in the region of 95 per cent of all applications.
In regard to the question of amending the legislation governing non-nationals generally, I would refer the Deputy to my answer to Question No. 84 of 2 April 1996.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the ending of Operation Shannon; the number of gardaí involved in that operation; the duration and effect of the operation; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am not in a position to provide the Deputy with the detailed information he has requested in relation to the number of gardaí involved in Operation Shannon on the grounds of security and crime prevention generally. The Garda authorities inform me that operations such as Operation Shannon are undertaken on an ongoing basis, nationally, to address both long-term and short-term operational needs in the fight against crime. These operations are subject to constant review and may change at any time depending on operational requirements. I understand that Operation Shannon was reviewed on an ongoing basis and on 9 April 1996, based on Garda assessment, it was further extended to take in adjoining areas. This new focusing of Garda resources is designed to meet the specific needs as identified by the Garda authorities and is, of course, subject to ongoing review.

The Garda authorities are not in a position to disclose the specific nature of their operations. However, I understand that, in general, local manpower backed up by specialist emergency response units and army personnel are deployed to the targeted areas as and when necessary. The implementation of all such operations is seen as playing an important role in the fight against crime on a number of fronts. The Garda authorities report that the results have been positive and encouraging in both low key and high profile operations carried out to date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Murder Statistics.

Qst.Quest: the total number of murders recorded during the first four months of 1995; the comparative figure for the same period in 1996; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that the information requested is as follows:

MainHeading.P: I am assured by the Garda that every possible effort is made to bring the perpetrators to justice. The detection rate for such offences is normally high. It is important to note that the above figures are provisional and, subject to the outcome of Garda investigations and or directions from the law officers, a number of these cases may be subsequently re-classified as manslaughter, etc.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Goldenbridge Orphanage Abuse Allegations.

Qst.Quest: the status of the investigation into allegations of abuse of children in Goldenbridge arising initially out of the broadcast of the "Dear Daughter" programme; whether there is an investigation into the alleged death of a baby (details supplied); and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: It is not the practice for the Minister for Justice to make statements to the House about the progress of individual Garda investigations except in singular instances where the circumstances of an investigation are so exceptional that such a course is deemed to be appropriate.
All I propose to say in this case is that I have been informed by the Garda authorities that investigations into the matters referred to by the Deputy are ongoing.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to implement the recommendations of the 1990 Martin Report relating to the treatment of persons in custody.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Martin committee report made two main recommendations. The first, concerning procedures for reviewing the cases of alleged miscarriages of justice, was dealt with in the Criminal Procedure Act, 1993. The second, on the audio-video recording of interviews with suspects in Garda Síochána stations, is at present the subject of pilot schemes at four selected stations. A steering committee under the chairmanship of Judge Esmond Smyth is overseeing those pilot schemes.

In addition, the Martin committee recommended two less pressing changes to the Treatment of Persons in Garda Síochána Stations Regulations, 1987. These can be incorporated in any future revision of the regulations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Medical Services for Prisoners.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, that has been made in the negotiations with the Irish Medical Organisation in relation to medical services provided for prisoners in Mountjoy Jail; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I would point out that while negotiations are ongoing between my Department and the Irish Medical Organisation they are not exclusively in respect of medical services being provided to prisoners at Mountjoy prison. While I accept that progress in the matter of negotiations has been slow, I am satisfied that every effort is being made to bring the negotiations, which are related to the terms and conditions of a proposed common contract, to an early and satisfactory conclusion.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Burglar Alarm Call-Outs.

Qst.Quest: the number of call-outs to burglar alarms in each of the last three years; the number of false or accidental alarm calls; the estimated amount of Garda hours wasted in responding to such false alarms; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is as follows:

MainHeading.P: Total alarm calls received:
Total number of false and accidential calls:

The Garda Síochána Alarm Policy is that after receipt of four false calls in any rolling six month period, the occupant of the premises is warned by written notice that Garda response will be withdrawn in the event of the number of false calls exceeding six. If the number of false calls exceeds six during this period, a written notice is served on the occupant that the Garda will no longer respond to alarm activiations from the premises.
Garda management estimate that an average of one man hour is spent in dealing with an alarm call, including time spent attending at the scene and any related paperwork.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tackling Crime.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to tackle the increase of up to 14 per cent in crime in parts of Dublin city.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I do not know the basis of the Deputy's claim that crime is up by 14 per cent in parts of Dublin. This may or may not be the case but I do know that official Garda statistics for 1996 so far suggest that crime is actually decreasing in the Dublin metropolitan area as a whole compared with the same period last year. I am sure that the Deputy will welcome this encouraging trend.

MainHeading.P: I have made the tackling of crime in all its forms my number one priority and I recently announced a series of measures, both immediate and long-term, to help deal with it. These measures include the provision of a significant number of prison places over the next 18 months, the implementation of the Garda restructuring plan, which provides for the creation of a regional command structure designed to improve the response to mobile crime, approval for the appointment of 15 new judges, steps to address the problem of drugs in prison and the management of addicted offenders, the early introduction of legislation in the criminal justice area and a new Garda information technology system.

Furthermore, in 1995, I established the Garda National Drugs Unit and the Garda National Bureau of Fraud Investigation. The Courts and Court Officers Act, 1995 will improve the efficiency of the courts and speed up trials. In addition, at community level, I have funded many youth diversion projects and other schemes to engage youth and steer them away from crime.
I believe that these measures will make a major impact in tackling crime, not just in Dublin but throughout the country.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Community Gardaí.

Qst.Quest: the number of community gardaí in the State; the plans, if any, she has to increase the number of community gardaí in line with requests from the public and neighbourhood watch groups; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The allocation of Garda personnel is the responsibility of the Garda authorities.

They have informed me that there are 246 members of the Force who are deployed full-time on community policing duties mainly in the urban areas of our larger towns and cities. In addition there are over 1,300 liaison gardaí servicing over 2,000 neighbourhood watch schemes in urban areas and over 800 community alert schemes in rural areas.

MainHeading.P: While I am convinced that the gardaí need to maintain the closest possible links with the communities which they serve, it should also be recognised that there is a limit to the number of gardaí that can be dedicated solely to this type of duty, given the overall demands on the Force. However, it is inherent in the function of all members of the Garda Síochána to provide a quality service to the public and the individual citizen through their interaction with the communities in which they serve. I am informed by the Garda authorities that the deployment of gardaí is under continual review by Garda management so as to provide a flexible policing service capable of responding to needs as they arise.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Crime Against Tourists.

Qst.Quest: the measures, if any, she has taken to ensure that the level of attacks against tourists is reduced in 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The issue of crime against tourists is one which receives the highest priority from my Department and the Garda authorities. Close co-operation is maintained with Bord Fáilte to ensure that crimes of this nature are minimised to the greatest possible extent.

MainHeading.P: The measures taken by the Garda to deal with this problem include the deployment of additional Garda patrols, both uniformed and plainclothes, in areas of high tourist interest. It has been noted that a limited number of locations feature in many instances of crime against tourists and these, of course, are targeted especially by the Garda. Other measures include the provision and distribution of an information leaflet by the Garda which is written in three European languages and which gives advice to tourists on how to protect their property and personal belongings. These leaflets are available at all sea ports and airports.

The presence of a Garda office, which opened in March 1990, in O'Connell Street, Dublin is also helpful. It serves as a central location for advising tourists on preventive measures. Another initiative has been the launch by the Garda community relations unit of a street map for tourists in Dublin, listing places of historical and current interest and also including crime prevention advice. Supervised car parks are shown on the maps. I understand that it is intended to extend this project to other areas frequented by tourists.

The Garda have carried out security surveys of all youth hostel accommodation. Advice has been given on securing entry and exit points to these buildings and providing facilities to allow tourists to store luggage securely.

For those tourists unfortunate enough to end up as victims of crime, there is the Dublin tourist victim support service which was launched on 14 April 1994 and which is being operated by the Irish Association for Victim Support (IAVS). The service, which is modelled on the Amsterdam Tourist Assistance Service, provides tourists who have been the victims of crime with help in overcoming the initial trauma of their experiences. The Garda Síochána have been involved in setting up this service and have provided premises for its operation at the Garda Dublin metropolitan area headquarters at Harcourt Square. A grant is provided to it by the Minister for Tourism and Trade. A co-ordinator with a victim support background has been appointed to head the team of volunteers who provide the service. They have a wide range of foreign languages and have received extensive training.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs
Qst.Quest: his views on whether this State should immediately ratify the UN Convention Against Torture; the legislative obstacles, if any, that exist to Ireland ratifying this Convention; and if so, the action, if any, he proposes in this respect.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring) Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Spring)
Speaker.P: Ireland signed the UN Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment on 28 September 1992. Early ratification of this Convention is essential.

Before Ireland can proceed to ratification legislation is necessary on the following issues: 1. Torture as defined in this Convention includes a category of mental torture for which an offence is not at present prescribed under the existing criminal law. 2. Legislation is required to expand the jurisdiction of our courts to cover alleged offenders who would not already be covered by the existing criminal law.

A review of existing extradition legislation may also be required to ensure compliance with article 3 of the Convention which states that “No State Party shall expel, return (refouler) or extradite a person to another State where there are substantial grounds for believing that he would be in danger of being subjected to torture”.

Responsibility for introducing the necessary legislation rests with the Minister for Justice. As soon as this legislation is enacted I will take steps to ratify this Convention as a matter of urgency.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to change the current rules whereby a public servant who has been ill for 56 days in any one year is debarred from seeking promotion; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: My response to this question is confined to the Civil Service, as my responsibility in this matter does not extend to the wider public service. In so far as the Civil Service is concerned, a person who has more than 56 days' sick leave in the preceding period of four years is considered unsuitable for promotion. This rule is applied in a flexible fashion. Absences for minor curative or “repair” operations, or absences due to non-recurring illnesses, may be discounted. If the candidate's sick leave record shows an improvement in the latter part of the four-year period, there is discretion to give him or her the benefit of the doubt.
I do not propose to change the current rules.

Qst.hpid: Éamon Ó Cuív Éamon Ó Cuív
Qst.Quest: the length of time it is taking the Western Health Board to process applications for renewal of medical cards; the action, if any, he intends to take to ensure that people who are entitled to medical cards are supplied with them on a continuous basis; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East)
Speaker.P: The responsibility for the determination of eligibility for medical cards rests with the chief executive officers of the health boards. I understand the procedure in the Western Health Board is that a review form is sent to the medical card holder at the beginning of the month in which the card falls due for review. The holder has 28 days in which to return the completed review form to the local community welfare officer. The community welfare officer then examines the documentation and may seek further information from the individual. Following receipt of the completed review form together with the recommendations and or observations of the community welfare officer, the chief executive officer then makes a decision to either review or cancel the existing medical card. The length of time this takes depends on the speed with which the card holder completes the review form and supplies any additional information requested by the community welfare officer.

A person's medical card remains valid and may be used until such time as the decision on renewal or cancellation is made. Those individuals who complete and return the form and also are deemed to be eligible are issued with new medical cards while those who fail to complete the review form are notified that their medical card is being cancelled and of the need to reapply.

I should point out to the Deputy that I issued instructions to all health boards in March of last year that review forms should not issue to persons aged 70 years and over. This was done to alleviate undue stress on persons in this age group whose circumstances are unlikely to have changed since their last review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Eligibility for Disabled Person's Maintenance Allowance.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: whether the amount of disabled person's maintenance allowance paid is affected by income earned by the spouse of the recipient; the changes, if any, he proposes to make in respect of this allowance; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East)
Speaker.P: Under section 69 of the Health Act, 1970 and regulations made thereunder, health boards, in assessing eligibility for disabled person's maintenance allowance, are obliged to have regard to the means of both the applicant and his/her spouse.

Recently I advised all health boards that all couples who in their own individual right are eligible for disabled person's maintenance allowance should in future receive two personal rates. Such couples, up to now, have been receiving a personal rate plus an adult dependant rate.

MainHeading.P: I am aware of differences between the assessment of means for disabled person's maintenance allowance and for social assistance schemes under the Department of Social Welfare. The spouse of a social welfare recipient on unemployment assistance is entitled to earn up to £60 per week, including travelling expenses, without affecting entitlement to this allowance. There is no similar provision under the disabled person's maintenance allowance regulations.

As the Deputy is no doubt aware, responsibility for the disabled person's maintenance allowance scheme is in the process of being transferred to the Department of Social Welfare. The Department of Social Welfare took over responsibility for the payment of disabled person's maintenance allowance on 1 August 1995. It is expected that responsibility for the administration of disabled person's maintenance allowance will transfer to the Department of Social Welfare in October 1996. I have no plans to change the existing disabled person's maintenance allowance regulations pending this transfer but this and other anomalies have been brought to the attention of my colleague, the Minister for Social Welfare, for consideration in any future changes to the scheme.

Qst.Quest: the activities, if any, currently taking place within his Department to encourage recycling; the current difficulties in respect of recycling of paper; his policy on the issue of recycling; the practical position in this regard in each local authority area; and the cost of recycling versus other means of refuse disposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 113 and 121 together.

MainHeading.P: I refer to the replies to Question No. 114 of 8 May 1996 and to Questions Nos. 142, 143 and 144 of 12 March 1996.

The strategy document Recycling for Ireland sets out the general approach being adopted by the Government to promote recycling to end 1999. The comparative costs of different waste management options have been analysed in the paper The Economics of Solid Waste Management in Ireland (November 1995) which was commissioned by my Department from the ESRI Environment Policy Centre. Both documents are available in the Oireachtas Library.

Difficulties in relation to the recycling of paper are being experienced at present in Ireland and many other countries arising from a significant reduction in the demand and price for waste paper. I intend to consult with other EU member states and the European Commission regarding possible international action to improve the situation.

Increased demand for recycled paper will be supported in Ireland by guidelines being finalised in my Department for environmental management by Government Departments. A study commissioned by my Department and National Newspapers of Ireland is also being completed by Teagasc on the use of shredded newspaper as bedding for dairy cows. These and other appropriate national measures to support waste recycling will be pursued by my Department in the context of the further implementation of the national strategy and of the Waste Management Bill, 1995.

Qst.Quest: the total amount of moneys received by all local authorities in 1995 from charge development levies; the amounts received by each local authority; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Annual planning statistics, which include details of development contributions, are compiled by my Department on the basis of returns from local authorities, and published. Planning Statistics 1994 is the most recently available and a copy is available in the Oireachtas Library. The 1995 statistics will be published as soon as possible after all the necessary returns are received from local authorities.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the concerns that new taxis being licensed are inaccessible to persons confined to wheelchairs (details supplied); and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The 1995 public service vehicles regulations specify standards for wheelchair accessible taxis which were first determined in 1992 following consultations with various interests, including those representing wheelchair users. It is a matter for the Garda commissioner to certify whether a vehicle is suitable to be licensed as a wheelchair accessible taxi in accordance with the regulations.

While I have no proposals to amend the 1995 regulations at this stage, I intend to review them in the light of experience of their operation and of submissions such as that referred to in the question. Recent representations received in my Department in relation to the specified dimensions for wheelchair accessible taxis will be examined in that context.

Qst.Quest: the current position in respect of an application made in 1992 by Mayo County Council for a sewerage scheme for Irishtown, County Mayo; and when the council will receive a response to its application.
the current position in respect of an application made in 1992 by Mayo County Council for a sewerage scheme for Kilmovee, County Mayo; and when the council will receive a response to its application.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 116 and 117 together. Briefs for the preparation of preliminary reports for the Irishtown and Kimovee sewerage schemes were received in my Department in November 1992 and February 1995, respectively. Having regard to the high level of commitments under the water and sewerage programme, it is not possible to state when the schemes will be advanced.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: A preliminary report for the Bohola sewerage scheme was received in my Department in April 1994. Having regard to the high level of commitments under the water and sewerage programme, it is not possible to state when the scheme will be advanced.

Qst.Quest: the survey, if any, his Department has carried out on a reed bed sewerage system for small sewerage works; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: In preparing the water and sewerage services capital works programme for 1996, my Department sought information from local authorities on their proposals for possible development of reed bed and other natural disposal methods. Subsequently, I announced the initiation of a `natural wetlands' subprogramme, and I approved individual schemes for Williamstown, County Galway, Boherbue and Cloyne in County Cork, and Ferns in County Wexford. In addition, a number of other schemes are being implemented by various local authorities.

All reed bed projects will be carefully monitored to assess their efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Further proposals will be considered on their merits to establish whether they might provide the optimum solution, environmentally and economically, when compared with other conventional engineering systems.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Waste Management.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: his policy in regard to incinerators and compost plants versus landfill sites for the disposal of refuse by local authorities; if it is the considered view that the average cost of a landfill site for a 30 year period is in the region of £12 million and the average cost of an incinerator and compost plant for a 15 year period is in the region of £10 million; and if he will consider greater use of incineration and compost plants as distinct from landfill sites which give rise to objections from local communities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The Government's recycling strategy has set an objective of increasing composting of municipal waste as a contribution to the overall target of diverting some 20 per cent of this waste stream from landfill. Grant assistance is available from my Department for this purpose. Proposals in respect of waste to energy projects have been invited by the Minister of State at the Department of Transport, Energy and Communications under the alternative energy requirement scheme.

MainHeading.P: The relative costs of various methods of waste management have recently been analysed in the policy paper The Economics of Waste Management in Ireland (November 1995) which was undertaken by the ESRI Environment Policy Research Centre and is intended to inform decision making by local authorities and other interested parties. A copy of the paper is available in the Oireachtas Library.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: if the passing of the Waste Management Bill, 1995 will bring any additional powers to the Environmental Protection Agency with regard to the designation of regional waste disposal sites; if the Environmental Protection Agency will have any powers in this regard, particularly with regard to designating existing county landfills as a regional landfill for neighbouring counties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The Environmental Protection Agency will be assigned a planning role under the Waste Management Bill, 1996 in relation to hazardous, but not non-hazardous, wastes. Waste management planning for non-hazardous wastes remains the responsibility of the major local authorities, acting individually or jointly. Powers to require joint or co-ordinated waste management plans from local authorities are conferred on the Minister for the Environment by the Bill.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the powers of a local authority to enter onto a landowner's property to investigate it for the purpose of considering the land for a landfill site; the extent of the powers of a local authority in this respect; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: General powers for entry by a local authority onto land are contained, inter alia, in the Public Health (Ireland) Act, 1878, and the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963.

MainHeading.P: Section 14 (9) of the Waste Management Bill, 1995, makes specific provision for entry by an authorised person onto land for the purpose of assessing the suitability of the land for waste disposal.

Qst.Quest: the reason the rate support grant for Carlow Urban District Council fell from £448,199 to £67,771 during the period from 1984 to 1995.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Rate support grant allocations to all local authorities, including Carlow Urban District Council, have been adjusted on a number of occasions from 1984 to 1995 to take account of various structural adjustments to the system of local financing during that period, including the removal from local authorities of a variety of levies and statutory demands, the writing-off of Local Loans Fund debt repayments, and the provision for direct rate payments by the ESB to local authorities. The effect of these adjustments must be taken into account in any comparison of the rate support grant allocation in 1995 with previous years' allocations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: Following consultation with the Environmental Protection Agency, I am satisfied that the incident of environmental pollution which occurred as a result of the recent accident at this plant does not warrant an investigation by the agency under section 104 of the Environmental Protection Agency Act, 1992. Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am not in a position at present to make remedial teacher posts available to primary schools.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Family Resource Centre.

Qst.Quest: the assistance, if any, that is available from her Department towards the provision of a family resource centre.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The Government is committed to promoting the active participation of parents at every level of the education process. It also supports the right of parents to be consulted, as part of a collaborative process for educational decision making and policy making at school, regional and national level.

MainHeading.P: As part of national education policy, it is essential to adopt a range of measures aimed at fostering active parental partnership with schools. At national level, the National Parents' Council is formally recognised as the representative body for parents at first and second levels. Parents are full partners in the consultative process between the Minister for Education, the Department and the other partners in education. Under the proposed legislation arising from the implementation of the objectives of the White Paper on Education, parents will be given a statutory entitlement to representation on each school board of management and each education board. A statutory duty will be placed on boards of management to promote the setting up by parents of a parents' association in every school in receipt of Exchequer funding. In the context of developing dynamic and supportive links between the home and the school, each board of management will be required, as part of its school plan, to develop a formal home school links policy.
If the Deputy has a specific initiative in mind, I would ask him to convey the details to me and I will have the matter considered within my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Special Schools Data.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the number of schools designated for special needs; their location; their admission procedures; the right of consultation for parents of children with special needs; the number of designated schools planned for each of the next two years; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There are 106 special schools which cater for children with special needs. Following is a complete list of these schools, including their names and addresses. In addition, there are 216 special classes attached to mainstream primary schools catering for children with special needs.
Children are referred to the special schools and special classes on the basis of psychological and other relevant assessments.

The White Paper on Education. Charting our Education Future, outlines the proposed future strategy for providing suitable education for children with special needs in either special educational facilities or in an integrated environment. The fundamental objective of the commitment in the White Paper is to ensure to the maximum possible extent that all children with special needs will have access to suitably resourced education services in their own area and within the ordinary school system. The degree to which integration can be achieved will depend on the specific and evolving capacities of the individual children concerned.

The rights of consultation for parents of children with special needs will continue to be an integral part of this process. The decision-making process, in relation to the replacement of a student in an ordinary and-or special school, will be a collaborative one, made by the parents and the professionals involved, with the objective of providing what is best suited to the child's development and needs.

The precise number of schools which will, over the next two years, be designated as centres where students with particular disabilities may be educated, as outlined in the White Paper, has not yet been determined.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the concern among parents of children with special needs that their children will be educated in a school reflecting their own religious ethos; the number of designated schools which are under the direction of a religious minority; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware of the concerns of parents of children with special needs in seeking to have their children educated in a school reflecting their own religious ethos.
