MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Transition Year Programme.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. McDowell Mr. D. McDowell
Qst.Quest: the number of schools which provide a transition year option for students; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Returns for the 1995-96 academic year, from the authorities of second-level schools, show that the transition year programme is being offered in 497 schools to a total of 24,036 students.

MainHeading.P: The Programme for Economic and Social Progress provided that a six year cycle of postprimary education would be made available for students commencing their post primary cycle in 1991. Accordingly, a restructuring of the senior cycle programme began which gave a three year senior cycle option from September 1994 consisting of a one year transition year programme and a two year leaving certificate programme with three orientations, the established leaving certificate, the leaving certificate vocational programme and the leaving certificate applied.

It is for the authorities of individual schools to decide whether to offer the transition year programme. In making this choice, schools are subject to the same constraints as apply to their general curriculum choice. Schools cannot always, for example, provide a range of curriculum or programme options to suit the wishes of every student.

Each year, my Department issues a circular letter to school authorities, inviting those schools wishing to provide a transition year programme in the following academic year to register with the Department. To date, 558 schools have indicated to my Department that they propose to provide the programme to a total of 28,162 pupils in the 1996-97 academic year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Junior Certificate Examination Eligibility.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. McDowell Mr. D. McDowell
Qst.Quest: the reason participants on vocational training opportunity schemes are not permitted to sit the junior certificate examination.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There is specific provision in my Department's rules for the admission to the junior certificate examination, in one or more subjects, of students following courses of study under the vocational training opportunities scheme.

Qst.Quest: the reason disadvantaged status has not been granted to the Presentation primary school, Carrick-on-Suir, County Tipperary in view of the fact that the two second level schools in Carrick-on-Suir have already been granted this status for the past number of years and the town of Carrick-on-Suir is also classed as disadvantaged.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: An application for disadvantaged status from the school in question was considered in my Department in 1994 in the context of an expansion of the disadvantaged areas scheme being undertaken at that time.
Unfortunately, the school did not rate high enough in terms of priority of needs to qualify for inclusion on that occasion.

In 1995, I commissioned the Combat Poverty Agency to conduct a detailed review of our current approaches to the identification and support of pupils suffering educational disadvantage. The criteria used to determine eligibility for inclusion in the disadvantaged areas scheme and the nature of supports to be provided were among the issues covered in this study.
As a result of the recommendations brought forward by the Combat Poverty Agency, I recently announced an important new targeted initiative in this area.
Under this new initiative, a special programme of intensified supports will be made available to selected urban schools and groups of rural schools.

The Education Research Centre has been commissioned to approach schools in the target groups and areas and invite their participation in this new initiative. I would expect that the schools in question will be contacted in the near future.

Qst.Quest: the priority, if any, that has been given to combating the serious and vicious escalating crime rate in Dublin in view of the fact that it is having a detrimental effect on the economy; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
her views on the concern of the general public at the rising crime levels, particularly vicious crime; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 134 and 147 together.

Garda statistics for 1996 so far suggest that crime is decreasing as compared to the corresponding period last year. This reduction in crime applies to both the Dublin Metropolitan Area and the rest of the country. Even so the level of crime is too high and I share the general concern with it.

I have, therefore, made the tackling of crime in all its forms my number one priority and I recently announced a series of measures, both immediate and long-term, to help deal with it. These measures include the provision of a significant number of prison places over the next 18 months, the implementation of the Garda restructuring plan which provides for the creation of a regional command structure designed to improve the response to mobile crime, approval for the appointment of 15 new judges, steps to address the problem of drugs in prison and the management of addicted offenders, the early introduction of legislation in the criminal justice area and a new Garda Information Technology system.

Furthermore, in 1995, I established the Garda national drugs unit and the Garda National Bureau of Fraud Investigation. The Courts and Court Officers Act, 1995 will improve the efficiency of the courts and speed up trials. In addition, at community level, I have funded many youth diversion projects and other schemes to engage youth and steer them away from crime.
I believe that these measures will make a major impact in tackling crime throughout the country.

Qst.Quest: the circumstances surrounding a recent fire in Mountjoy Prison; the person(s), if any, who was responsible; and the medical condition of the person(s) concerned at the time of the fire; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The fire at the health care unit in Mountjoy on 18 December 1995 was started deliberately by a prisoner who, by so doing, put the lives of staff and other prisoners at risk. As a result of the fire 13 prison officers and six prisoners were taken to the hospital, of whom two officers and four prisoners were detained overnight. No staff or prisoners were seriously injured.

All fire response procedures, practices, physical infrastructures and training are being reviewed as a priority by my Department in close consultation with the prison authorities and the relevant expert agencies.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, made regarding the transfer of prisoners from Britain to Ireland; the concerns, if any, the British Home Office has in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: A total of 89 Irish prisoners in British prisons have applied for or expressed an interest in transferring to Ireland under the provisions of the Transfer of Sentenced Persons Act, 1995. A total of 29 of these applications have been formally transmitted by the UK authorities to date. I have been in a position to give my formal consent to five of these applications. The remaining applications are currently under examination in my Department, some in consultation with various other offices, including the Chief State Solicitor's office and the Home Office. The Deputy will be aware that one of the applicants, whose transfer I consented to, arrived back in the State yesterday. One further application is at an advanced stage of processing and I hope the applicant will be transferred back shortly.

It is unclear as to what the Deputy means by concerns that the British Home Office have in this regard. My Department and officials from the Home Office are in regular contact concerning the transfer of sentenced persons and are unaware of any particular or outstanding concerns on the British side.

Qst.Quest: her views on whether it would be beneficial to extend the Garda retirement age from 57 to 60 years; if so, the matters, if any, preventing her from approving such an extension; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the consideration, if any, she has given to extending the Garda retirement age; her views on the benefits arising from such a retirement age extension; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 140 and 141 together.

I understand that the representative associations for each of the ranks of the Garda Síochána up to chief superintendent at present have claims before the Garda Conciliation Council to have the retirement age extended for their respective ranks.

As the Deputy is aware, the scheme of conciliation and arbitration for the Garda Síochána provides the relevant machinery for the processing of such claims. Under the terms of the scheme the proceedings of the council are confidential and it would not be appropriate for me to comment further.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the difficulties that some Garda stations experience when they require a replacement motor vehicle; the number of vehicles allocated to each Garda station in the areas of Dublin 1, 3, 5 and 9; whether she has satisfied herself with existing arrangements; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The allocation of Garda resources is the responsibility of the Garda authorities. They have informed me that, contrary to what the Deputy states in his question, Garda stations are not experiencing difficulties when they require a replacement motor vehicle. This is due to the fact that a replacement vehicle is normally made available to any station where it is envisaged that the permanently allocated vehicle is going to be out of service for a period of time. The Garda authorities also inform me that existing arrangements are satisfactory to meet present policing requirements.

The Garda authorities are responsible for the detailed allocation of Garda resources and personnel to different areas. Postal divisions and Garda divisions do not share the same geographical boundaries. The following are details of mobile units allocated according to Garda districts:

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, that has been made by the multi-disciplinary approach and other actions to address the escalating problems associated with drug misuse; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Government recognises that the drugs problem is multi-faceted, requiring a response from a number of Departments and agencies. In this regard, the Deputy will be aware that last year the Government approved a series of organisational, financial, legislative and operational measures to deal with the drugs problem. A further series of measures — concerning education, prevention and treatment issues — was agreed by the Government in February.

It would be difficult, in the context of an answer to a parliamentary question, to set out in detail the progress made on an item-by-item basis on the implementation by all the Departments and agencies concerned of all the measures in question, but the Deputy may be assured that significant progress has already been made and will continue to be made.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, made on the study being undertaken to determine the effect on the demand for prison places if there was a change in the bail laws; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Any indication of the effect on demand for prison places if there were to be changes in the bail laws would, of course, depend on the precise nature of these changes and, accordingly, would have to await the finalisation of proposals for change in our bail laws. In devising proposals in this area I have had full regard to assessments of the likely implications of possible changes in the law in this area for prison accommodation requirements.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Assaults on Bus Drivers.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, that has been made by the working group to examine incidents of assaults, robberies, larcenies and damage to Dublin Bus drivers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The working group established by me in November 1995 to consider the problem of assaults on bus drivers and other related matters has concluded its work and completed a report. It contains a number of recommendations on practical measures that can be taken to reduce such incidents and also identifies longer-term policy and legislative measures that might be considered in addressing the problem. I am, at present, reviewing the report.

Qst.Quest: the total number of prison places not in use; the current position regarding female accommodation for prisoners in Mountjoy Prison; whether the top landing is in use; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The position is that all usable prison places are currently occupied. There are 43 female prisoners currently in custody in Mountjoy prison. They are accommodated on two floors of D-Wing, St. Patrick's Institution. The remaining floor of D-Wing is in full use since late February this year and 33 young male prisoners are now held there.

At the health care unit at Mountjoy prison, 38 out of the total of 57 prisoner places in the unit have been out of use following extensive fire damage on 18 December 1995. Refurbishment and fire safety upgrading works at the unit are almost complete and the unit will be returned to full use within the next two weeks.

At Portlaoise prison a total of 60 prisoner places are not in use at present. This is due to operational requirements in relation to the accommodation and management of different groupings of prisoners at this high security prison. Construction works are under way to facilitate rationalisation of accommodation arrangements, thus permitting use of all prisoner places at this prison. These works are due for completion this year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Land Registration.

Qst.Quest: when registration for adverse possession will be dealt with by the Land Registry in respect of a person (details supplied) in County Limerick; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that this dealing refers to an application under section 49, i.e. acquisition of title by virtue of long possession of the Registration of Title Act, 1964, which was lodged on 22 March 1995. I understand that due to their complicated nature, applications under section 49, which require detailed examination of the applicants claim for registration as owner, take time to process.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rural Garda Stations.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to examine the possibility of re-opening rural Garda stations in view of the increase in attacks on the elderly in rural areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Contrary to public perception, no Garda stations have been closed as a result of the community policing scheme for rural areas. The main aim of the scheme is to forge closer links between the Garda and communities they serve. Prior to the introduction of rural community policing many Garda stations were open round the clock, a situation which was found to be unnecessary because of the low level of personal calls. Now stations are open at set times to transact such administrative business as is necessary, based on detailed assessments of the administrative workload. For the rest of the time the gardaí, who would otherwise be deskbound, are engaged in active and operational duties in the community, moving around in that community and getting to know all the people they serve. During the hours when stations are unmanned any caller to the station can make direct contact with a garda on duty at the district headquarters by using the direct communication link which is available at each Garda station involved in the rural community policing scheme. The gardaí at the district headquarters can then arrange for the nearest Garda or mobile patrol unit to come to the assistance of the member of the public. Under the scheme fixed opening hours of rural Garda stations are now guaranteed and this was not always the case in the past.

MainHeading.P: The rural community policing scheme has a number of very positive benefits for those living in the communities in which it operates, including vulnerable groups such as the elderly. It involves a more effective use of available resources. Community gardaí are now mobile and provide a more flexible service to the public by way of faster response to calls. They can maintain contact with elderly residents in remote areas in the course of normal patrols. The gardaí in these areas have been able to acquire broader local knowledge and a wider degree of contact with the public. The scheme has also facilitated greater involvement by the gardaí in community based crime prevention programmes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Under-Age Late Night Drinking.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to address under-age late night drinking; and the proposals, if any, she has to review late night extensions.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Section 35 of the Intoxicating Liquor Act, 1988, makes it an offence for a licensee to allow any person under 18 years of age, with an exception for employees, on any part of his or her licensed premises during the time an exemption is in operation in that part. It is also an offence for the person who is under 18 years of age to be on the part of a licensed premises where an exemption is in operation. The 1988 Act also amended the special exemption order provisions as they relate to Sunday night-Monday morning.
While all aspects of the liquor licensing laws are kept under continuing review, I have no proposals at present to amend those laws.

Qst.Quest: if she will make a statement on the operation of neighbourhood watch schemes; and whether these schemes make a worthwhile contribution towards limiting crime in our community.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: Neighbourhood watch schemes provide an extremely effective and valuable vehicle for community involvement in crime prevention. While it is difficult to quantify, the Garda believe that such schemes play a vital part in preventing crime in those areas where schemes are in active operation. They also provide an essential mechanism for bringing gardaí and local communities closer together. For my part, I am committed to the development of the neighbourhood watch programme and, in this regard, I have directed officials in my Department to carry out an evaluation and assessment of all community based initiatives to ensure that all areas of the country are adequately covered.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Qst.Quest: if he will review the recent compulsory introduction of A9 PRSI contributions in respect of persons on community employment projects.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: Class A PRSI provides cover for the full range of benefits and pensions available under the social insurance system. The extension of this PRSI class to community employment workers will enhance their PRSI status and put them on a par with other class A workers. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Family Resource Centres.

Qst.Quest: the assistance, if any, that is available from his Department towards the provision of family resource centres.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: My Department funds a community development programme, with an allocation of £4.46 million in 1996. The programme provides financial and other assistance to projects towards the staffing and equipping of local resource centres which provide a focal point for community development activities in the area and to other specialist community development projects. The projects provide a range of supports, development opportunities and services to community groups and individuals in their areas.

MainHeading.P: Quite a few of the projects in the programme make work with families a particular priority in their workplans. Moreover, in 1994, to mark the International Year of the Family, a special allocation of £250,000 was made available under my Department specifically for family resource centres. Following from this allocation, ten such centres are being funded by my Department at a cost of £155,000 in 1996.

The emphasis in the community development programme is on personal development aimed at developing the individual's confidence and assertiveness so as to enable him-her to engage more fully with society. The programme is essentially about promoting positive change in society in favour of those who benefit least from economic development. A key principle is that projects be managed by a management committee on which people who themselves experience poverty and exclusion participate. The aim of the community development programme is not the provision of social services, professional counselling or social work, although such services are sometimes provided as an outcome of the project's work.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to make provision for the division of child dependant allowances on a pro-rata basis between separated spouses who have agreed shared custody arrangements in their legal separation agreements; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The question of dividing child dependant allowances on a pro rata basis between separated spouses, who have agreed shared custody arrangements, raises the issue of parents who both fulfil a contingency on an equal but partial basis. Current provisions focus on issues, such as the normal residence of the child, and the question of maintenance, in determining the payment of child dependant allowances in cases where parents have separated. The allocation of these payments on a pro rata basis has significant policy and administrative implications across a range of social welfare schemes, and these are being considered by my Department in the context of the introduction of the one-parent family payment in early 1997.

Qst.Quest: the measures, if any, he has considered introducing to address the problem of escalating unemployment figures; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. R. Bruton) Richard Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. R. Bruton)
Speaker.P: A part from the ongoing activities of the agencies, FAS, Forbairt, IDA Ireland, SFADCo and the county enterprise boards, the Government has been responding to the particular problem of long-term unemployment through a variety of targeted measures. These include the development of more employment friendly taxation and social welfare regimes and the introduction in this year's budget of a series of precisely targeted employment measures: the splitting of the community employment, CE, programme into two distinct options — a part-time integration option and a part-time jobs option — and the better targeting of the programme at the long-term unemployed; the introduction of a new pilot whole-time jobs option; the introduction of a new recruitment subsidy scheme called Jobstart; the introduction of a new work experience programme called Work-Place; the introduction of special measures for 18-19 year olds; the extension of the back to work allowance scheme; and the retention of certain benefits for those returning to work.

The establishment of the local employment service represents an important component of the Government's response to tackling long-term unemployment. The distinctive additional elements of this service, in providing an individually tailored progression path towards employment for its clients and ensuring that there is well co-ordinated employment service delivery at local level, should yield real benefits in terms of securing employment for long-term unemployed persons, as the service develops. The fact that it is initially launched in 14 areas, including the major unemployment black spots in the country, means that it is first being targeted where it is most crucially needed.

My plans for 1996 are that the local employment service should be consolidated in these 14 areas and subject to an initial evaluation before the service is expanded on a planned basis to other areas. In this way we can ensure that the service is developed to maximum effect for its client population.

Training is an another important component in any measure of active labour market interventions aimed at addressing the problems of long-term unemployment, given the strong link between low levels of education attainment and long-term unemployment. I will be addressing this problem in the White Paper on Human Resource Development which I will be submitting to the Government shortly for consideration.
I have already published a strategy paper on the labour market and this will be followed by papers later this year on enterprise strategy, services and longer-term planning.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the reason the recent benchmarking decisions in respect of key aspects of performance adopted by the Government and contained in the Moriarty report have not been implemented in the semi-State companies under the aegis of his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: The Government decision referred to in the Deputy's question states that price competitiveness and performance benchmarks should be established as part of the corporate planning process of each State enterprise that has a dominant or monopoly position in the Irish market.
